Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework Version: 5 Author/Owner: Information Security Manager/Chief Information Officer Document version history Purpose The purpose of this document is to provide Wannon Water with a framework for ensuring a standardised, repeatable method for detecting and managing cyber security incidents. A cyber security incident is any event that threatens the security, confidentiality, integrity or availability of the organisation’s information and operational assets. The framework and processes set out in this document align to Wannon Water’s Cyber Resilience Strategy, the business Emergency Management Plan (EMP), and the best practice standards for cyber security incident management (NIST 800-61 and ISO-27035).
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

This Framework document should be read in conjunction with the individual cyber incident management plan scenario playbooks (Playbooks) to ensure a robust and holistic approach is taken to managing cyber incidents. The individual Playbooks provide the Wannon Water Information Security Incident Response Team (ISIRT) with step by step instructions for each of the following incident types: Data Breach Third Party Data Breach Ransomware Phishing System Compromise Denial of Service (DOS)
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Having an effective incident reporting and investigation framework enables Wannon Water to meet legislative obligations, ensure lessons are learned from incidents occurring, and help identify controls to prevent reoccurrence. Wannon Water is exposed to numerous incidents of varying type and severity levels ranging from incidents that can be managed on-site locally (e.g. an isolated security breach) to wide scale incidents involving service disruption across multiple systems. Scope In scope The Wannon Water Cyber Security Incident Management Framework encompasses the identification and management of incidents: in the Information Technology (IT) domain; in the Operational Technology (OT) domain;
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

that are defined in the EMP and have as a contributing root cause a cyber security event. For example, the compromise of an OT SCADA system by software infection which ultimately impacts water flow or water quality would involve the instigation of cyber incident management processes (the Playbook linked to System Compromise) under this framework, as well as the instigation of incident management processes related to the non-cyber impacts of the compromise (as per the EMP). Out of scope The following items are considered out of scope for the application of this framework:
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

The management and treatment of Incidents that are not related to cyber security factors and do not have cyber security issues as a contributing cause of any incident (i.e. no impact to systems, technology or data and no causes related to the materialisation of cyber security threats). Business continuity or business response beyond technical IT and OT controls. Incident Management Lifecycle Cyber Security Incidents are managed in accordance with the guidelines set out in the NIST 800-61 Incident Response Lifecycle and accord to four main phases. These phases represent the application of best practice incident management processes: Preparation Detection & Analysis Containment, Eradication & Recovery Post-Incident Activity Figure 1 shows a visual representation of the 4 phases.
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

This document examines all 4 phases from a holistic standpoint, whilst the individual Playbooks (representing incident scenarios) focus on the fine details of phases 2 and 3. Where there is variation from what is described in this document for phases 1 and 4, this is detailed in the individual Playbooks. Figure 1 – NIST 800-61 Incident Response Lifecycle The EMP sets out 3 levels of severity for the classification of incidents – in order of increasing severity: (i) Operational, (ii) Enhanced Operational, and (iii) Incident Management Team (IMT). Each level also has increasing levels of incident complexity, employee involvement, resourcing, internal liaison and external liaison. Impacts from a cyber security incident are commonly graded on a severity scale with 5 levels: None/negligible;
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Minor; Moderate; High; Very High. Refer to Appendix A for a detailed description of the cyber security incident impact types against these severity levels. A formal declaration of a cyber security incident could ultimately lead to the declaration of an Emergency, as defined in the EMP (p14). In this instance, procedures for cyber security incident remediation and Emergency remediation may be applied conjunctionally to aid in incident recovery. Response This document sets out how to deal with cyber security incidents as per the 4 phases defined in the previous section: Preparation Detection & Analysis Containment, Eradication & Recovery Post-Incident Activity
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Each phase will be detailed in this section. The information hereafter should be considered in conjunction with the Playbook relevant to the incident scenario. Preparation Figure 2 – Preparation phase of the Incident Response Lifecycle Overarching responsibility for implementing the incident response framework for Wannon Water falls to the Information Security Incident Response Team. The ISIRT is an organisational function that covers the process for information security incidents and is focused mainly on IT security incidents. At a bare minimum, the members of the ISIRT accord with the following organisational roles: Information Security Manager IT Operations Manager Chief Information Officer Manager Risk & Resilience Enterprise Network Technical Lead
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Additional members may be recruited into the ISIRT from time to time as needed to meet the requirements of incidents as they occur. Incident response methodologies typically emphasise preparation—not only establishing an incident response capability so that the organization is ready to respond to incidents, but also preventing incidents by ensuring that systems, networks, and applications are sufficiently secure. Although the ISIRT is not wholly responsible for incident prevention, its role is fundamental to the success of incident response programs. Additional measures to ensure adequate preparation for the occurrence of a cyber security incident are listed as follows:
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Ensure an updated and reviewed contact matrix is maintained, detailing key contacts both within and external to Wannon Water. Information to include email addresses, phone numbers, and if applicable public encryption keys. Refer also to the Core Services Map documents for critical system ownership and information; On-call information and escalation criteria; Established incident management and risk reporting system, supported by issue tracking and problem management functionality (e.g. IRIS or equivalent risk management system); Secure storage systems for securing incident history, forensic evidence etc.; 24 hour/365 days monitoring of key security variables (logging and event management) via a dedicated Security Operations Centre (SOC);
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Cyber security education, training and awareness programs (supported by, for example, phishing awareness campaigns); Vulnerability management programs to detect and mitigate system security vulnerabilities; In-house or externally available digital forensic capability, including evidence gathering resources such as chain of custody forms, digital cameras, audio recorders, evidence storage bags etc.; Configuration Management Database (CMDB) to include configuration items for all critical systems, Operating Systems (OSs), applications, network devices, and secure configuration baseline for critical systems; Network diagrams and listings of all critical digital assets (e.g. servers ,databases and OT devices);
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Documentation for OSs, applications and network security appliances (e.g. firewalls and intrusion detection systems); Ready access to clean images of Standard Operating Environment (SOE) OS and key applications, to aid in restoration and recovery. These artefacts should be a part of a data and system backup management plan. Adherence to a published schedule for testing the Cyber Security Incident Response Plan and Playbooks via simulation or tabletop exercises. These will be used to assess the adequacy and effectiveness of the Framework and should feed into the Lessons Learned aspect of Phase 4. Configuration documentation, where available, for OT devices. Detection and Analysis Figure 3 – Detection & Analysis phase of the Incident Response Lifecycle
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Cyber security incidents are highly variable in nature, so capturing common characteristics for all of them is not possible. An incident can evolve from a cyber security event that does not conform to expected behaviour or parameters. This type of event may or may not lead to the formal identification of an incident (See Appendix D). Once a particular incident has been identified (for example, Ransomware), the appropriate Playbook should be consulted and read in conjunction with this document. Following detection and analysis, incident triage and classification will need to be applied. Detection: The detection of a cyber security incident can come from many sources. The most common for Wannon Water would include: Security Operations Centre alerting/notification End user/employee
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Wannon Water Customer Helpdesk Vendor Vulnerability assessment Audit Analysis: At the point of notification, it is not certain that the alert will result in a formal incident being identified. It is the task of the ISIRT to determine if an incident is to be declared by applying a triage and classifying the incident. Triage will determine the incident severity, and the classification will determine what Playbook/s should be consulted for progressing incident remediation. Considerations for the ISIRT include: Assessment of risk Determine scope of impact – IT and / or OT? Is company proprietary data involved? Is Personally Identifiable Information (PII) involved? Interview the notification source/s
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Identification of affected systems and information assets, including the BIL ratings of impacted information. Data collation Criticality of the systems involved Where OT systems are involved, the businesses capacity to continue operations with those systems degraded or unavailable During the Triage and Classification process, the ISIRT should convene and initiate a conference call with all concerned stakeholders. Although the primary reason for gathering evidence during an incident is to resolve the incident, it may also be needed for legal proceedings. In such cases, it is important to clearly document how all evidence, including compromised systems, has been preserved. Evidence should be collected according to procedures that meet all applicable laws and regulations which have been developed from previous discussions with legal staff and appropriate law enforcement agencies. This is to ensure that any evidence is admissible in court. In addition, evidence should be accounted for at all times: whenever evidence is transferred from person to person, chain of custody forms should detail the transfer and include each party’s signed authorisation. A detailed log should therefore be kept for all evidence.

Applying a triage will help to determine the incident severity and classification. Given that the full impact and root cause of the incident may not be immediately evident, investigations should continue until this is established. Determining whether a particular event is actually an incident is sometimes a matter of judgement. It may be necessary to collaborate with other technical and information security personnel to make a decision. The key objectives of the meeting for the ISIRT and other conference call attendees should be to: Perform an incident analysis based on the evidence provided and the source data. Consider the method of detection and any people involved in the escalation to the ISIRT;

Containment: Containment is important to ensure that the incident doesn’t overwhelm Wannon Water’s resources or produce additional ongoing impacts to systems or information assets. Containment provides time for developing a tailored remediation strategy. An essential part of containment is decision-making (e.g. whether to shut down a system, disconnect it from a network, disable certain functions etc.). Such decisions are much easier to make if there are predetermined strategies and procedures for containing the incident. Wannon Water manages this risk through the use of detailed Playbook instructions to deal with containment.
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Containment strategies vary based on the type of incident. For example, the strategy for containing an email-borne malware infection is quite different from that of a network-based dDoS attack. Refer to the correct Playbook for full instructions. Eradication:  After an incident has been contained, eradication may be necessary to eliminate incident symptoms, such as deleting malware, disabling breached user accounts, as well as identifying and mitigating all vulnerabilities that were exploited. During eradication, it is important to identify all affected servers and endpoint devices so that they can be remediated. For some incidents, eradication is either not necessary or is performed during recovery. Follow the Playbook instructions for effective eradication steps.
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Recovery: Implement the Playbook requirements to assist with effective incident recovery. Examples may include administrators restoring systems to normal operation and confirming that the systems are functioning normally. Recovery may involve such actions as restoring systems from clean backups, rebuilding systems from scratch, replacing compromised files with clean versions, installing patches, changing passwords, disabling any vulnerable services or components, and tightening network perimeter security (e.g. firewall rulesets and boundary router access control lists). Higher levels of system logging, network monitoring or the deployment of additional security controls are also often part of the recovery process. Once a resource is successfully attacked, it is often attacked again, so full recovery should be robust and completed in conjunction with the Lessons Learned section below.
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

In summary, the ‘Containment, Eradication and Recovery’ phase is a critical part of the Incident Response Lifecycle, the main objectives of which are as follows: Confirm the criticality of data and systems effected (referring to the relevant Wannon Water Incident Response Playbook), and assign prioritised remediation tasks and follow-up timeframes so that the relevant support teams can contain the incident; Remove all signs, symptoms and causes of the incident from affected systems to ensure the problem is eradicated; Recover and restore systems as necessary to resolve the incident;
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Provide updates to identified stakeholders in line with the Communications Plan (see Appendix C), notify any affected users of the incident remediation, and if required, notify the regulatory authorities (dependent on the nature of the incident). Incident Closure: Close out all linked service tickets updating details as necessary and capturing process remediation requirements as identified. Send incident closure email to relevant staff as identified on the Communications Plan. Post Incident Activity / Lessons Learned Figure 6 – Post Incident Activity phase of the Incident Response Lifecycle
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Once the incident has been closed, post incident activities should be conducted and should incorporate a ‘Lessons Learned’ aspect. A post-incident review should cover off points to enquire whether the incident was managed effectively with a view towards incorporating any potential improvements into the management of future incidents. These should include: Confirmation that the incident has been resolved and the Incident Log is reviewed for closure; Initial mitigation strategies review–- Was the incident contained? Was process followed, and were the right people involved? Communications review – were the correct people notified as per the Communications Plan and were updates timely and accurate? Were all incident activities recorded appropriately?
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

Were any outstanding or unresolved issues or vulnerabilities captured in the problem management system or risk management system (IRIS)? This will be required for mitigation of like impacts during any future incidents. Review remediation activities – did the restoration activity work as expected? Was required system documentation available and accurate? Are any updates required for the incident response documents and framework? Update process, framework and Playbook documentation accordingly in line with the lessons learned.
Cyber Security Incident Response Plan Framework.DOCX

An effective Incident Response Framework should involve testing the Plan and Playbooks on a regular basis. This can take the form of exercises or simulations of varying complexity (from a simple tabletop simulation right up to a full test of all aspects of incident management just as if a real incident had occurred). The schedule for testing of the plans should be published and adhered to, with the outcomes of the testing feeding into the Lessons Learned component of incident management. RESPONSIBILITY

Purpose The Digital Change Management Process is the practices and processes used to maximise the number of successful changes to Digital services and products, through ensuring that risks have been properly assessed, authorising changes to proceed and managing the change schedule. It is defined through the following ecosystem of documents: This document, the Digital Change Procedure, provides day to day guidance on completing the activities required to plan, approve and implement changes. This procedure is system agnostic.  The associated document “Digital Change Guideline - SDP Guide” provides detail on how these activities translate into the Wannon Water’s IT Service Management tool - ServiceDesk Plus. Scope
Digital Change Procedure.docx

This procedure applies to any employee or contractor in Wannon Water who is involved in the change process (including change requests) where the change will be made to a Digital Platform overseen by a Change Authority. Procedure Overview Change Category The Digital Change Procedures varies according to the Change Category. Note that Business as Usual changes are out of scope for the Digital Change Management Procedure. Change Workflow Broadly, changes progress through the following stages: Procedure – Overview Change Design
Digital Change Procedure.docx

This step takes place before the change record is entered into the ITSM tool.  The objective of this step is to translate the need for a change into well designed change records.  Well considered design avoids rework and sets the change(s) up for a smooth approval process, as well as making it more likely that they will be successful. The key aspects of change design are: Change category. Related changes. Change risk. These are described in more detail in the following sections. Change Categorisation When the need for a change is confirmed, one of the first steps should be to confirm the Change Category, using the definitions described in Section 3.1 Change Category.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

It is expected that the Change Owner and Change Authority consider the risk and complexity of the individual change to inform the categorisation. The category, combined with change risk, will determine the lead time required for approval of the change, and should be considered when scheduling the change implementation window. In determining the category, the Change Owner and Change Authority should consider the guidance below: If a Change Owner identifies a change which appears to be consistent with one of the pre-approved changes on the agreed list, they should ensure that the change is: Consistent with the definition of the pre-approved change category (routine, repeated and low risk). Consistent with the definition and intent of the specific pre-approved change.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

If there is any doubt that it meets these criteria, it should be raised as a normal change. An emergency change is a change which is required to prevent or respond to a major incident.  Normal changes where an urgent implementation is desired due to considerations outside this such as staff availability do not meet this definition.  In these cases, the Change Authority and Change Owner should work with the Change Manager to see if the approval process can be expedited. Related Changes Related changes occur when: There is a single change which needs to be applied multiple times across multiple instances.  For example, applying a certificate to multiple apps/servers; migrating sites over to a new telecommunications protocol.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

Staggered rollouts. For example, rollout of an application update to laptops and desktops. When planning these changes, the Change Owner and the Change Authority should work with the Change Manager to determine whether one or multiple changes should be raised. When determining this, the following should be considered: Whether the change risk varies across the different change components. Whether the planning varies across the different change components. The requirement for a meaningful audit trail for anyone who might be scheduling a change or investigating an incident on the same service/infrastructure. In making this decision, the Change Owner and Change Manager should consider the guidance below:
Digital Change Procedure.docx

If the change rollout is staggered as part of good practice to minimise the impact in the very unlikely situation that something goes wrong, it is reasonable to include all the stages in one change record. If the first stage is a pilot, and the learnings will be used to inform future state, then multiple changes are more appropriate to allow for easier changes to schedules or implementation plans. A change record which runs over an extended period does not support easy identification of what has changed when.  Unless otherwise agreed with the Change Authority and Change Manager, a change record should not cover a period of more than 5 days.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

If in doubt, default to more change records rather than less.  This avoids situations where a failure, alteration or rescheduling of just one part of the change requires the whole change to have to be resubmitted and reapproved. Change Risk The change risk is determined using Service Criticality and Probability of Failure. These are applied to determine a risk level according to the risk matrix below. Note that the approval requirement for a normal change varies depending on the risk of the change. Service Criticality
Digital Change Procedure.docx

Services are defined to support the change process, and each has been assigned a criticality which reflects its importance to Wannon Water.  The Change Manager will keep a record of the services and associated criticality, as well as the ITSM service definition including criticality. Criticality is assessed according to the following definitions: High – failure of this service would result in immediate/direct risk to public or employee health or safety or pose a significant environmental impact. Medium – this service is used daily by many employees or is used by a department to deliver a time critical core process or service to stakeholders or customers.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

Low – not core to day-to-day service delivery and would usually support processes which can be deferred until the system is available or there is a straightforward workaround or manual fallback. Probability of Failure “Probability of Failure” includes a broad range of scenarios, including the change being unable to be implemented, the implementation not going to plan or the change causing incidents or issues after implementation.
Digital Change Procedure.docx

This is assessed considering factors such as the number of systems or assets being impacted by the change, the amount of effort to design, build and plan the change, the inherent stability and complexity of the service, the complexity of the implementation, confidence in the rollback procedure and whether a similar change has been successfully completed previously. Procedure – External Change An external change is a change being made to Software as a Service or externally managed infrastructure, where the change is not initiated by Wannon Water, and Wannon Water has no control over the timing or content of the change. Once a clear definition is agreed, the Change Authority should provide the details to the Change Manager. The Change Manager should update the ITSM tool, update the pre-approved change audit log and update all impacted change process participants. The Change Manager should update the ITSM tool, update the pre-approved change audit log and update all impacted change process participants. Scenario 2: Change is in Approval or Implementation Stage but has yet reached implementation date. The procedure to close the change should be consistent with the procedure for the applicable change category. The Change Manager will co-ordinate the completion of the PIR with the Change Owner and Change Authority and any other stakeholders. The PIR focusses on learnings to improve change outcomes going forward.  The exact approach and scope of this may vary, but at a minimum will cover: Learnings which could help avoid recurrence of the issue. Learnings which could help reduce any adverse impacts if the issue recurs. Identification of actions which were completed which positively impacted the change outcome and should be adopted as common practices or incorporated into procedures. If the change went smoothly or if there are clearly no learnings, the Change Authority can waive the requirement for a PIR. Related Processes

In the case where the PIR process identifies a reportable event, a recommendation will be included in the PIR for the Change Authority to raise a risk incident. PURPOSE To outline the procedure and directives for the correct use of the Outlook (i.e. email) system at Wannon Water. Phishing e-mails can appear to come from legitimate institutions such as your bank, credit card company, etc, but they usually come from a criminal trying to steal information.
Email Usage Procedure.DOCX

Phishing can be avoided by following these guidelines: Never send sensitive account information in an e-mail message. Never go to a sensitive site through an e-mail link; always type the site name directly into your browser (such as www.commbank.com.au). Never give any password out to anyone. If your bank requires verification, do it over the phone or in person. Verify any person who contacts you unsolicited, claiming to be customer support. Employee Departures Procedure.DOCX

After a resignation letter has been received and accepted by their line manager, People and Wellbeing will formally accept the resignation in writing on behalf of Wannon Water. closing out any outstanding financial processes. For a complete list of all actions required upon departure, refer to the employee departures checklist. Process for when Personal Sick Leave and Carer’s/Family Leave is exhausted In the event that an employee has exhausted all Personal Sick Leave and Carer’s/Family Leave entitlements the employee is permitted to access other leave accruals to cover these absences. Employee Leave Procedure.DOCX

Parental Leave is available to full-time, part-time and eligible casual employees as outlined in the WWEA. To request Parental Leave the following steps must be taken: An employee wishing to take leave must provide the following to the RC at least 10 weeks prior to each proposed period of Parental Leave: Complete a paper based Application for Leave form notifying the dates of which the employee proposes to start and finish the period of Parental Leave. A certificate from a registered medical practitioner, which states the expected date of confinement, or states the date on which the birth took place. The employees Manager/Supervisor must authorise the paper based application. Parental Leave may be taken in conjunction with Annual Leave, Long Service Leave, Special Leave Without Pay or RDO.

NB: Employees do not accrue RDO’s while on Parental Leave. Government Paid Parental Leave (Centrelink) This is a government funded entitlement for working parents who are the primary carers of a child born or adopted from 1 January 2011. An eligible person can receive taxable Parental Leave Pay at the rate of the national wage for a maximum of 18 weeks.
Employee Leave Procedure.DOCX

The employee will apply to the Family Assistance Office (within Centrelink), who will then decide if the employee is eligible, if eligible Centrelink will inform Wannon Water of the payment arrangement. Payment to the employee will take place as part of the normal fortnightly Payroll cycle, and will take place after funds have been received via Centrelink (no payments will be made until this is completed). Government Paid Parental Leave is taxable but is not liable for Employer Superannuation. Leave entitlements do not accrue on the taking of this type of leave. On 1 January 2013, the Government introduced a new form of Paid Parental Leave – this payment is for Fathers and Partners. It is a 2 week payment at the minimum wage and is assessed by Centrelink in the same manner as the above.
Employee Leave Procedure.DOCX

However, Wannon Water will not be involved in making payment to the employee; this will be paid directly by Centrelink. A key eligible criterion is that the Father or Partner cannot be on paid leave with Wannon Water; they must be on pre-approved unpaid leave (please refer to section 4.14 on how to apply for Special Leave Without Pay). Employee Leave Procedure.DOCX

PURPOSE To inform Wannon Water employees of the appropriate completion, submission, and approval procedures for the lodgement of their fortnightly timesheet, which will result in the payment of their fortnightly wage. To ensure that all employee costs transactions are authorised and paid accurately, efficiently, and in a timely and secure manner, and are captured in the financial records of the Corporation. This document is regarded as a policy for Financial Management Compliance Framework (FMCF) requirements. SCOPE All Wannon Water employees are required to complete and submit a fortnightly timesheet to ensure the timely payment of their fortnightly wage.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

The only employees exempt from timesheet submission are the Board of Directors. These employees are paid via an Exception Entry (Autopay) mechanism. This procedure applies to all employee costs transactions of Wannon Water. INSTRUCTIONS Timesheet Types Wannon Water employees are provided with three (3) standardised timesheet templates: Ordinary Hours – Technology One Ci Anywhere (CiA) version. Ordinary Hours – Excel version. Overtime Hours. Ordinary Hours A properly formatted Ordinary Hours timesheet must be completed by each employee throughout the duration of the current fortnightly payroll period to ensure the payment of their wages. Wannon Water’s indoor workforce must do this by completing the standardised timesheet template enclosed within the application: CiA.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Whilst, Wannon Water’s outdoor workforce must do this by completing the standardised timesheet template enclosed within a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. Each entry listed on the Ordinary Hours timesheet should reflect employee hours worked, start and finish time worked (only applicable for the outdoor workforce), an appropriate description, an account code (as defined per the chart of accounts as outlined by the Finance and Regulation Branch), and any employee leave paid or unpaid taken during the payroll period. Please refer to the Employee Leave Procedure for more detail. Approval of Timesheets The completed Ordinary Hours timesheet must be submitted to the employee’s direct-line Manager/Supervisor for review.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water’s indoor workforce must click on the orange Submit button to ensure their Ordinary Hours timesheet is submitted to their direct-line Manager/Supervisor for review. Whilst, Wannon Water’s outdoor workforce must ensure their Ordinary Hours timesheet is submitted as an e-mail attachment to their direct-line Manager/Supervisor for review. Approved Ordinary Hours timesheets, by the direct-line Manager/Supervisor, are to be forwarded onto the Remuneration Coordinator. If the Ordinary Hours timesheet is forwarded via e-mail (only applicable to outdoor workforce who submit excel based timesheet), it should include an appropriate e-mail trail approval comment, for example ‘Approved’, to clearly indicate that the Ordinary Hours timesheet has been reviewed and is approved for payment.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

It is the employee’s responsibility that their fortnightly Ordinary Hours timesheet is completed and submitted on a timely basis. Failure to meet this requirement will see the employee’s wage being delayed for payment. The held payment will instead be processed as part of the next fortnightly payroll period, providing the approved Ordinary Hours timesheet has been received. Ordinary Hours timesheets submitted without approval will generally not be processed for payment unless the direct-line Manager/Supervisor is unavailable due to ill health, an emergency, or has not designated a person to act on their behalf. Under these circumstances, the Remuneration Coordinator will process and seek approval when the direct-line Manager/Supervisor is available.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

The Remuneration Coordinator must receive approved Ordinary Hours timesheets by no later than 12:00pm on the last day of the payroll period i.e. Friday. Ordinary Hours timesheet excel templates can be provided upon request by the Remuneration Coordinator. Overtime Employees who are required to work overtime hours must complete an Overtime Hours timesheet. Employees must do this by completing the standardised timesheet template enclosed within a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet. Each entry listed on the Overtime Hours timesheet should reflect employee hours worked, start and finish time worked, an appropriate description, and an account code (as defined per the chart of accounts as outlined by the Finance and Regulation Branch).
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Overtime Hours timesheets must be submitted as an e-mail attachment to their direct-line Manager/Supervisor for review. Approved Overtime Hours timesheets, by the direct-line Manager/Supervisor, are to be forwarded onto the Remuneration Coordinator, and should include an appropriate e-mail trail approval comment, for example ‘Approved’, to clearly indicate that the Overtime Hours timesheet has been reviewed and is approved for payment.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Approved Overtime Hours timesheets should be submitted to the Remuneration Coordinator by 12:00pm on the last day of the payroll period i.e. Friday. For employees required to work on the last weekend of the payroll period i.e. Saturday and Sunday, overtime timesheets are required to be forwarded onto the Remuneration Coordinator by 9:00am on the Monday after the finish of the payroll period. Overtime timesheet excel templates can be provided upon request by the Remuneration Coordinator. Payroll Processing
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Prior to the finalisation of the payroll process, a Payroll Audit Report shall be produced from the SQL Server Reporting Services system. This report outlines the employee master file alterations that have been undertaken within the prior fortnight, and shall be reviewed and signed as correct by the Branch Manager Finance and Regulation (or their delegate). Ordinary Hours and Overtime Hours timesheets (produced in a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet) shall be entered into the Technology One Ci HRP system, in accordance with the processes outlined in the Payroll Procedure.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Following the completion of the timesheet input into Technology One, a Payroll Calculation Report shall be produced from the system. This report ensures all employees are paid correctly, and that costings reflect accurately the employee’s attendance and activity for the period. Where practical, a review of the report should be carried out by a member of the Finance and Regulation Branch who did not enter timesheet data. Following the review of this report and processing of any review adjustments, authorisation shall be provided to finalise the payroll process. Leave Balances
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Employee leave balances (i.e. leave accrued and taken) are updated in finalising the payroll process. Prior to the payment of wages, a Leave Balances Report shall be produced from the system. This report is reviewed by the Remuneration Coordinator to see if the update has resulted with an employee leave balance going into the negative. If this has occurred, the employee in question will be asked to change their taken leave (to another leave type) to ensure their leave balance does not remain in the negative.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Where practical, leave balances are to be monitored with a view to ensuring they are minimised at all times to avoid any significant impact upon Wannon Water’s cash flows. Leave balances are to be maintained in accordance within the accepted limits outlined in the Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement. Payment of Wages
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Payment of wages shall occur via an electronic file transfer (EFT), suitable for transmission through WIBS into Wannon Water’s banking software (i.e. Westpac Banking Corporate Online). Following the successful transmission, dual authorisation of the EFT is required by Wannon Water officers with appropriate delegation. The EFT will be transmitted in a timely manner to ensure wages payments are deposited by no later than Wednesday after the end of the payroll period. Should a public holiday fall on the preceding Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, deposit of wage payments will be delayed by the number of public holidays that fell on the preceding Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

To ensure the payment of an employee’s wage whilst on extended leave (i.e. Annual Leave or Long Service Leave), it is the employee’s responsibility to complete and submit, prior to commencing their leave, the appropriate number of fortnightly Ordinary Hours timesheets for the coverage of their leave. Failure to comply with this condition may see the employee’s salary being held over to a later payment date. Ordinary Hours and Overtime Hours timesheets (enclosed within a Microsoft Excel spreadsheet), and their accompanied approval e-mail trail, are printed, processed, and filed for reference in a hardcopy format (to comply with Internal Audit requirements).
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

A completed and submitted timesheet by an employee (regardless via the CiA or Microsoft Excel standardised timesheet template) is a declaration that it is a true, accurate, and binding record of hours worked, at training, or on leave. A timesheet submitted electronically to their direct-line Manager/Supervisor is considered as a signature for this purpose. Pay Advices Pay Advices shall be distributed via e-mail to employees in a timely and secure manner, in accordance with the processes outlined in the Payroll Procedure. Employee Costs Transactions Employee costs transactions shall be disbursed to the Technology One Ci General Ledger in a timely manner, in accordance with the processes outlined in the Payroll Procedure. Payroll Reports
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Records of each payroll shall be printed and/or retained for future review, in accordance with the processes outlined in the Payroll Procedure. Personnel Files All personnel files shall be held in a secure location under the direct control of the Executive People and Resilience (or their delegate). Access to the information held within personnel files is restricted to the following, under the supervision of a member of the People and Wellbeing Branch: The Remuneration Coordinator. The employee. The employee’s direct-line Manager/Supervisor. The employee’s General Manager. The Managing Director (or their delegate). RESPONSIBILITY
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

All employees are required to complete and submit a fortnightly Ordinary Hours timesheet to ensure the timely payment of their fortnightly wage, with the exception of the Board of Directors. The Branch Manager Finance and Regulation, and the General Manager People and Business Services are responsible for employee costs transactions. The Remuneration Coordinator is responsible for maintaining this procedure and for processing of the fortnightly payroll runs in line with the payroll procedure. DEFINITIONS Payroll period: a period of two (2) weeks from Monday to Sunday. DOCUMENTATION The following standardised timesheet templates are referenced throughout: Ordinary Hours. Overtime Hours. The following documents are referenced throughout: Employee Leave Procedure. Payroll Procedure.
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX
Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement. REFERENCES Fair Work Act 2009. DOCUMENT CONTROL
Employee Timesheet and Costs Procedure.DOCX

Purpose The primary purpose of the Executive Employment Committee is to assist the Board in fulfilling its corporate governance responsibility in relation to executive employment and remuneration, including: Oversee the implementation of the Executive Remuneration Policy approved by the Board Recommendations to the Board regarding executive remuneration and employment Ensure Wannon Water offers a competitive remuneration package to attract and retain a Managing Director of high calibre to deliver the strategic directions set by the Board Ensure compliance with relevant regulatory and legislative obligations, as well as consider authorising environment expectations
Executive Employment Committee Charter.DOCX

The Committee is responsible for oversight of all inclusion and diversity initiatives where they relate to executive employment, in alignment with the We are Wannon Strategy, including ensuring the implementation of the Gender Equality Action Plan Oversee the development and implementation of succession plans for the Managing Director and Board Secretary Facilitate the process of the Board setting annual performance plans for the Managing Director and Board Secretary and the assessment of actual performance against those plans Scope The Executive Employment Committee is a formally appointed Committee of the Board and as such is responsible to the Board.
Executive Employment Committee Charter.DOCX

The Committee’s authority is established by Board resolution and is in accord with the requirements of the relevant legislation and the Victorian Government Public Entity Executive Remuneration Policy (PEER). Membership Committee members shall be appointed by the Board and the Committee shall consist of at least three non-executive Directors.  Two non-executive members of the Committee present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum. The Chairperson for the Committee shall be the Chair of the Board. Become familiar with the PEER Policy and executive employment roles of Victorian Public Sector Commission (VPSC) and the Victorian Independent Remuneration Tribunal (VIRT). The Committee is responsible for the: The annual review of the Executive Employment Committee Charter and forwarding any proposed amendments to the Board for consideration. Ensuring that the Managing Director undertakes the annual review of the performance of the Executive Team and periodic review of remuneration packages of the Executive Team having regard to PEER Policy, VPSC and VIRT guidelines and the performance of the individual executives. Consulting with the Board to undertake an assessment of the actual performance of the Managing Director in delivering the targets and objectives set for the Managing Director in annual performance and development plans approved by the Board to determine the quantum of performance based remuneration of the Managing Director The oversight of the preparation and implementation of succession plans for the Managing Director and other key executive and management positions for review and approval by the Board

Monitoring executive remuneration and employment contracts of the Managing Director and other executive managers for compliance with PEER Policy and report annually to the Committee Consulting with the Board to undertake an assessment of the actual performance of the Secretary to the Board in delivering the targets and objectives set for the Secretary to the Board in annual performance and development plans approved by the Board Dealing with any other matters delegated to the Committee by the Board Compliance with, and periodic review, of the Wannon Water Executive Appointment Decision Making Framework that considers current public sector expectations around criteria for Executive appointment. Meetings and Support
Executive Employment Committee Charter.DOCX

Meetings will be held on an as needs basis but not less than twice a year.  Meetings shall be convened by the Chairperson of the Committee. The Committee may seek independent professional remuneration advice as required. Such advisers should have existing market databases or demonstrate other ability to access market information relating to public sector organisations. The Managing Director and the Executive People and Resilience, or other appointed management support, shall be responsible for submitting reports to the Committee in accordance with the Committee’s annual agenda calendar.
Executive Employment Committee Charter.DOCX

The Executive People & Resilience, Board Secretary, Executive Assistant or other appointed management support, shall provide support to the Committee as required, having regard to the need for confidentiality. Chairperson The Chairperson of the Committee shall: Ensure that the Board is informed of the scheduled meeting dates of the Committee Oversee the preparation of Committee meeting agendas Monitor that reports are submitted to the Committee in accordance with the Committee’s Annual Calendar Submit reports to the Board on behalf of the Committee as required Receive and submit to the Committee for noting all correspondence received from the VPSC and VIRT regarding executive employment and remuneration issues
Executive Employment Committee Charter.DOCX

Represent Wannon Water in discussions with the VPSC and VIRT regarding executive employment and remuneration issues which may arise from time to time Liaise with the Chairperson’s of the Executive Remuneration Committees of other Victorian water corporations regarding executive remuneration matters as needed Reporting To measure if this Charter is being implemented successfully, Wannon Water will have regard to the following: Document version history

Purpose To ensure that all expenditure transactions are appropriately authorised and incurred in accordance with business needs, and are captured in the financial records of the Corporation. This document is regarded as a procedure for Financial Management Compliance Framework (FMCF) requirements. Scope This procedure applies to all expenditure transactions of Wannon Water. Procedure Revenues are defined in the Statement of Accounting Concepts (SAC) 4 as: consumptions or losses of future economic benefits in the form of reductions in assets or increases in liabilities of the entity, other than those relating to distributions to owners, that result in a decrease in equity during the reporting period.. The criteria for the recognition of revenue as defined by SAC4 is:
Expenditure Procedure.DOCX

An expense should be recognised in the operating statement, in the determination of the result for the reporting period, when and only when: it is probable that the consumption or loss of future economic benefits resulting in a reduction in assets and/or an increase in liabilities has occurred; and the consumption or loss of future economic benefits can be measured reliably. Timely and accurate recording of expenditure All expenditure transactions shall be recorded in the Corporation’s financial system, Technology One, in a prompt, complete and accurate manner, in accordance with approved policies and procedures.  The following guidelines shall be followed: Identification and recording of expenditures incurred irrespective of any subsequent cash flow.
Expenditure Procedure.DOCX

Expenditure shall only be incurred when duly approved (as per the Instrument of Delegation, Appointments and Authorisations), with regard to available budgets and for authorised purposes. Invoices shall be recorded in the Corporation’s financial system in accordance with approved procedures, so as to avoid duplication of payments. Payments shall only be made on receipt of compliant tax invoices (and in some circumstances, invoice) or in accordance with the relevant ATO tax rulings of the time, with instances of compliance on-compliance monitored by the CFAO or their delegate.
Expenditure Procedure.DOCX

An audit trail of expenditure transactions within the Corporation’s financial system shall be maintained. Expenditure shall be recorded in accordance with Corporation procedures so as to comply with the requirements of Australian accounting standards board and Australian Taxation Office regulations. Approval of expenditure Expenditure transactions shall only	be approved by officers in accordance with the Corporation’s Instrument of Delegation, Appointments and Authorisations. Where practical, the following duties shall be segregated: Initiation of expenditure. Approval of expenditure. Receipt of goods and services. Invoice verification and processing. Disbursement and payment processing. Maintenance of vendor records.

On a monthly basis, purchasing reports are provided to Managers, to enable review of expeniduture approved within delegation, by their direct reports. Payables management Payment of amounts outstanding to creditors shall be managed so as to take advantage of full payment terms inclusive of the receipt of early payment discounts where available. Payables technology The Corporation shall make payments in a safe and efficient manner taking advantage of the latest payment technologies available. Purpose Wannon Water actively supports measures to reduce family violence, promotes health and safety of employees and recognises that employees will be amongst those affected by situations of family violence. Guidelines This document has been developed to comply with the Essential Services Commision’s Customer Service Code requirements. Responsibilities of managers when an employee discloses their experience with family violence Managers and team leaders have the responsibility to: Provide a sensitive and non-judgemental approach; Discuss measures to prioritise safety in the workplace and make all reasonable efforts to provide a safe work environment for the employee; Refer the employee to the EAP to enable support;
Family and Domestic Violence Guidelines - Managers and Leaders.DOCX

Make the employee aware of the Wannon Water Family Violence Procedure; Work with the employee to accommodate their requirement for adjustments, flexible work options and leave; Maintain confidentiality and privacy at all times, using the “need to know” philosophy; Ensure ongoing communication and regularly check in with any affected employee; Maintain relationship with employee as manager, not the role of counsellor; Ensure appropriate management of work performance and monitoring of attendance issues. The employee should not be adversely affected as a result of experiencing family violence. Steps to follow if an employee discloses their experience with family violence A disclosure of family and domestic violence is when an employee makes known that:
Family and Domestic Violence Guidelines - Managers and Leaders.DOCX

They are experiencing family and domestic violence. An immediate family member is experience family and domestic violence. A member of an employee’s household is experiencing family and domestic violence. At Time of Disclosure Listen, be non-judgemental, compassionate and caring; Acknowledge the employee is in a difficult situation and thank them for disclosing to you; Reassure the employee that their safety is important to you; Assess the situation as to whether the employee is in immediate danger, and if police or other support service need to be called;
Family and Domestic Violence Guidelines - Managers and Leaders.DOCX

Advise the employee that Wannon Water can provide support to the employee if they wish to make a police report, however, Wannon Water cannot make a police report on their behalf; Ask the employee if there are any changes that can be made to make them feel more comfortable at work; Reassure the employee that you care for their wellbeing and that this disclosure will not adversely affect their job; Reassure them that their information will be kept strictly confidential and will not be recorded without their permission, however People & Wellbeing may need to be informed regarding their disclosure in order to access some support options. Provide information Provide them with a copy of or refer them to the Family Violence Procedure
Family and Domestic Violence Guidelines - Managers and Leaders.DOCX

Refer them to the Employee Assistance Program (EAP) to access free counselling sessions. Family and Domestic Violence Guidelines - Managers and Leaders.DOCX

Keep in regular contact with the employee to ensure communication remains open; Respect the employee’s privacy and boundaries, even if in disagreement with their decisions regarding their relationship; Monitor the wider team and speak to any other employee who seems to be affected, referring them to the EAP in the first instance. If an employee at risk of family violence does not disclose, no further questions or speculations should be made. The manager must avoid judgement of the employee due to the disclosure, and their behaviour towards that employee must not change. At time of disclosure

Listen without judgement; Acknowledge that it must have been hard for the employee to disclose. Reassure the employee that this disclosure will not adversely affect their job, however using work time or resources to cause any violence against another person will not be accepted; Reassure them that their information will be kept strictly confidential and will be recorded on their file with their permission; Provide information Provide them with or refer them to the Family Violence Procedure, taking the time to explain the key points to them; Refer them to the Employee Assistance Program (EAP) to access free counselling sessions. Purpose Wannon Water is continually looking to implement and evolve workable and innovative flexibility options consistent with our values and operating environment. Wannon Water believes we can provide additional benefits to employees as they look to deliver on team and organisational objectives. This procedure provides guidance to both employees and managers on flexible working. Scope This procedure applies to all employees and does not alter nor override the terms and conditions of the Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement 2020. Procedure Wannon Water recognises the potential benefits of providing flexible working arrangements to assist employees with balancing the demands of work with their family and/or personal responsibilities.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Flexible working arrangements can also benefit businesses by increasing staff attraction and retention, decreasing absenteeism, and achieving greater productivity through increased employee job satisfaction. Flexibility is also an enabler of improved gender outcomes and financial inclusion. Positive working relationships, trust, performance, and regular communication between employees remains critical to the success of flexible work practices and an organisation’s ability to continue to evolve flexible working. Principles Wannon Water’s approach to flexibility is supported by principles that guide employees and managers to have open and transparent conversations around what might and might not be available for each situation.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Principles that need to be considered as part of all flexibility opportunities include: Zero Harm and the values of trust and integrity remain at the core of flexible work. Every role should be able to access some form of flexibility, noting not all types of flexibility will work for every role. What is or is not possible for some, should not limit what is possible for others. Wannon Water remains predominantly a physically present workforce due to the benefits this brings. Managers and employees are to have open conversations and work together to explore what might be workable. There is no expectation that employees must work flexibly, or feel that they need to work flexibly.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Flexibility will need to reflect and consider our current operating environment and how we work, however this should not be a barrier to considering new opportunities or ways of working. Flexibility is subject to review if performance, service, or Zero Harm outcomes are reduced or are at risk or if the needs of the wider team change. An individual’s flexibility agreement must not: materially change the nature of work for an individual create ongoing additional work or stress for the individual, manager or other employees negatively impact the ongoing achievement of team and organisational objectives rely on a requirement to back fill by contractor, consultant or other means. Types of Flexible Working Arrangements Employees can access forms of flexible working arrangements including:
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Variation to work hours (or worksite / remote work) Adhoc Flexibility Purchased Leave Model (48/52, 49/52, 50/52, 51/52) Work From Home (WFH) Transition to Retirement Regular access of accrued leave. Variation to work hours (or worksite / remote work) An Individual Flexibility Arrangement is an agreement under Clause 17 of the Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement to vary work hours (and days) on an ongoing basis. An employee can apply for an Individual Flexibility Arrangement to amend their start and finish times by a margin of up to 45 minutes or reduce their meal break of 45 minutes by 15 minutes to a minimum unpaid meal break of 30 minutes. Alternatively, any employee may wish to increase their unpaid meal break to a maximum period of 1 hour 30 minutes.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

An employee can apply to modify the spread of working hours over a working week to increase the number of hours worked on a particular day, (to a maximum of 9.5 hours), therefore lessening the amount of hours worked on other day(s) during the week. This arrangement may also cover work site start and finish locations for a particular day or work pattern. Either party can terminate an Individual Flexibility Working Arrangement giving 28 days’ notice, or earlier by agreement. Adhoc Flexibility (up to one hour) Nominally there are no provisions for short (up to one hour) absences from the workplace without applying for some type of leave, however, Wannon Water permit short duration ad hoc absences on a ‘give and take’ basis where a foundation of trust exists.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Employees may request to take up to a one-hour absence from the workplace to meet personal commitments on a give and take basis. Employees wishing to access ad hoc flexibility should discuss with and receive permission from their manager before any absence occurs. Managers are responsible for ensuring that absences are irregular and based on ‘give and take’. For regular absences an employee will need to apply for an Individual Flexibility Arrangement. Purchased Leave (48/52, 49/52, 50/52, 51/52) Employees may request to access a Purchase Leave arrangement, providing the employee the opportunity to purchase up to 4 weeks additional leave, over 12 months, in return for a pro-rata reduction in their salary. Refer the Purchase Leave procedure.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

All employees other than casual or fixed term (less than 12 months) are eligible to apply for Purchased Leave. Purchased leave enables an employee to request up to four additional weeks of leave over a 12 month period, in return for a pro-rata reduction in their salary. This reduction is averaged out over 12 months and as such, approval is on the basis that it is a 12 month fixed term agreement. Employees are to indicate in their required for Purchased leave when the additional leave is planned to be taken. Any   variation to the period of planned leave must be approved by the relevant manager and the Remuneration Coordinator is to be notified in writing of the approved leave amendment.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

An approved Purchased Leave arrangement will remain in place until the 12 month expiry date. In only specific instances, as outlined in the Wannon Water EBA, an employee may apply for the purchased leave model of employment to cease before the nominal expiry date. An employee participating in a Purchased Leave Model of Employment will become a fractional employee at the relevant fraction of a full-time workload, with all benefits accruing on that basis over the 12 month period. The commencement of a Purchased Leave Model of Employment must be at the start of a pay period or where agreed at the commencement of the next anniversary date of commencement of employment.
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Purchased leave must be taken within the approved 12 month period in blocks of 5 consecutive leave days. All purchased leave accrued under the Purchased Leave Model of Employment must be used before the 12 month period expires. An employee with more than 15 weeks of long service leave accrued will be required to utilise those entitlements before applying for purchased leave. Superannuation
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

Where an employee elects to take up the Purchased Leave Model of Employment, Wannon Water shall only be obliged to pay employer superannuation contributions at the applicable pro-rata rate. Where an employee chooses to maintain superannuation contributions at their full-time employment basis rate they can do so, subject to the requirements of the relevant superannuation scheme, via additional pre and/or post tax superannuation contributions. Cessation of Employment
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

An employee who discontinues their employment whilst on the Purchased Leave Model of Employment will be paid for unused purchased leave at the appropriate rate. Where other entitlements have accrued at the full-time rate, any termination payments will be made at the full-time rate. Where an employee has exceeded their pro rata entitlement to purchased leave, this will be deducted from the employee’s final pay. Review of Arrangements

An employee may apply for the Purchased Leave Model of Employment arrangement to cease before the 12-month expiry period for circumstances relating to changes of an individual’s personal financial demands or other exceptional circumstances. In these circumstances, the employee will be requested to use all of their additional purchased leave. If an employee has utilised more purchased leave than they have paid for through payroll deductions arrears will continue to be deducted from the employees pay until reconciled. Parental Leave
Flexible Working Arrangements Procedure.DOCX

This flexibility provision aims to provide eligible employees access to parental leave for both primary and secondary caregivers depending on their individual circumstances. Wannon Water also offers flexible return to work options for employees returning from parental leave. For more information, see clause 49 of the Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement 2020. Wannon Water is committed to providing a safe and healthy place of work for employees, including those who because of their role and circumstances, can undertake some work from home. Work from home for the purposes of this procedure means an employee’s place of residence and is different to “remote work” or “work site”. There are two categories of WFH that might be available. An ongoing arrangement that is formalised through an Individual Flexibility Agreement as part of a normal work pattern; and An informal Short Term WFH arrangement in response to a one off or short term change of circumstances.

Both opportunities require pre-qualification. As per all flexibility options at Wannon Water, any agreement must adhere to Wannon Water’s flexibility principals for them to be successful. WFH is subject to additional criteria including: Suitability of the role for work from home; Employee performance and core competency considerations; Productivity will be maintained or increased; Suitable work environment at home; Internet connectivity, access to Citrix and work systems and programs relative to role requirements; Impact on others (team and other internal and external stakeholders); Aligning where possible to “team days”; Cannot be a substitute for caring duties; and Any other considerations that may be identified based on individual circumstances.

All terms and conditions of employment that apply whilst working on-site at Wannon Water remain unchanged and are applicable to work from home. Impact on employee and career development activities and experiences; The need to undertake a WFH e-learn module every 12 months; WFH is not provided as an opportunity to avoid workplace conflicts or interpersonal problems that may be occurring; and Employees agree that Wannon Water is not responsible for any liability claim by a third party except to the extent caused by the negligent act, error or omission of Wannon Water. Purpose This policy states how our organisation: responds to offers of gifts, benefits and hospitality; and provides, benefits and hospitality. This policy is supports individuals and Wannon Water to avoid conflicts of interest and maintain high levels of integrity and public trust. Wannon Water has issued this policy to support behaviour consistent with the “Code of Conduct for Victorian Public Sector Employees” and the “Code of Conduct for Directors of Victorian Public Entities” (the Code). All employees are required under clause 1.2 of the Code to comply with this policy. Scope This policy applies to all workplace participants including Directors, employees, contractors, consultants and any individuals or groups undertaking activity for or on behalf of Wannon Water. Policy statement
Gifts Benefits and Hospitality Policy - BOARD.DOCX

This policy has been developed in accordance with requirements outlined in the minimum accountabilities for the management of gifts, benefits and hospitality issued by the Victorian Public Sector Commission. Wannon Water is committed to and will uphold the following principles in applying this policy: Impartiality - individuals have a duty to place the public interest above their private interests when carrying out their official functions. They will not accept gifts, benefits or hospitality that could raise a reasonable perception of, or actual, bias or preferential treatment. Individuals do not accept offers from those about whom they are likely to make business decisions. Accountability - individuals are accountable for: declaring all non-token offers of gifts, benefits and hospitality;
Gifts Benefits and Hospitality Policy - BOARD.DOCX

declining non-token offers of gifts, benefits and hospitality, or where an exception applies under this policy, seeking approval to accept the offer; and the responsible provision of gifts, benefits and hospitality. Individuals with direct reports are accountable for overseeing management of their direct reports’ acceptance or refusal of non-token gifts, benefits and hospitality, modelling good practice and promoting awareness of gifts, benefits and hospitality policies and processes. Integrity -  individuals strive to earn and sustain public trust through providing or responding to offers of gifts, benefits and hospitality in a manner that is consistent with community expectations. Individuals will refuse any offer that may lead to an actual, perceived or potential conflict of interest.
Gifts Benefits and Hospitality Policy - BOARD.DOCX

This is further expressed through Wannon Water’s value of integrity, and demonstrated with the behaviours of: Being open, honest and impartial Being accountable for the commitments made ;and Being fair to myself and others. Risk-based approach - Wannon Water, through its policies, processes and Audit and Risk Management Committee, will ensure gifts, benefits and hospitality risks are appropriately assessed and managed. Individuals with direct reports will ensure they are aware of the risks inherent in their team’s work and functions and monitor the risks to which their direct reports are exposed. Purpose The purpose of this procedure is to clearly describe how hazards are identified, reported, assessed and controlled within Wannon water. Scope This procedure applies to all functions, sites and systems of work undertaken within Wannon Water by employees, contractors and the general public. A hazard is any object or any work practice that has the potential to cause: injury or illness (to employees, contractors, visitors or general public), including both physical and psychosocial environmental or natural asset damage problems or issues with water quality property and/or infrastructure damage or loss disruption to service supply damage or loss of ICT networks loss or damage to data (hard copy or electronic) unauthorised access to any facility or asset managed by Wannon Water
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

environmental or natural asset damage, or an impact on product quality Wannon Water’s reputation to be compromised. The Hazard Reporting process can also be used for identifying opportunities, including physical, procedural and system improvements. Procedure – Hazard Reporting Process The purpose of hazard reporting is to work out the underlying causes of the hazard which will; prevent any incident that may result from the hazard correct the problem and to prevent a recurrence explore opportunities to improve our processes and systems allow analysis of data. Hazards can be identified in several ways, including Workplace inspections, Task Risk Assessment (TRA/JSA), HACCP Processes, Audit programme, day to day business activities (e.g. the use of procedures).
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

Where an exisiting process, i.e., Workplace Inspections, TRA, audit etc., results in a hazard being identified, raised and actioned, there is no need to log an additional hazard. The system can be used where beneficial but is not required. Below is an overview of the process for hazard reporting; Hazard Identification and Reporting It is the responsibiltiy of all employees to report any hazards they come across. All identified hazards should be reported as soon as practicable into RiskWare. Guide on how to report a hazard can be found in Content Manager; . The person who will own/manage the hazard should be consulted as part of the process to ensure they understand the details of the issue and are the correct person to manage it. Hazard Assessment
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

All reported hazards need to be assessed in RiskWare. Our target is to complete a hazard assessment within 30 days of the hazard being reported. The hazard assessment includes assessing what action has already been taken, what the risk is at the time of the hazard being reported, control measures required and what the risk is/will be after controls have been implemented. Guidance is available on how to complete this in RiskWare (). Risk Rating Hazards are assessed against our operational risk consequence categories and risk matrix (). These are programmed into RiskWare and can also be found in so:control. This step involves: Determining the likelihood that an incident will occur Determining the consequences of the incident Calculating the risk score (which may range from low to extreme)
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

Implementing Control Measures All hazards must be managed as per our Risk Appetite using the following hierarchy of control, as far as reasonably practicable. The hierarchy of controls has five levels of actions to reduce or remove hazards and the levels are ranked from highest level of protection and reliability through to lowest. Elimination is the most effective control measure and should always be used where possible. If it is not possible to eliminate the hazard, then you must eliminate as many of the risks associated with the hazard as possible. Administrative and PPE controls are less effective and reliable controls. These should only be used: as last resorts when there are no other practical control measures available
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

as an interim measure until introducing a more effective way of controlling the risk to increase the effectiveness of higher-level control measures in addition to other controls Communication of Hazards It’s important that we always share information about hazards with other people where it might affect them. This is to ensure other areas can understand and apply any outcomes or learnings where applicable hazards may exist. Hazards/learnings can be communicated in a number of ways, inlcuding: OHS Representatives / OHS Consultative Committee Safety or Zero Harm Alerts Team/Toolbox meetings Watershed post, emails etc. Monitor and Review
Hazard Reporting Procedure.DOCX

After implementing a control measure, it should never be assumed that the control measure is effective. New control measures may also introduce hazards of their own. For this reason, all hazards and controls should be assessed on an ongoing basis. Roles and responsibilities Definitions Governance Document version history

the actual requirements of the position for the proposed Higher Duties period; reflection of the commercial reality of the difference between banding levels as defined in the Wannon Water Enterprise Agreement (accountability and extent of authority, judgment and decision making, specialist knowledge and skills, management, interpersonal skills, qualifications and experience): the time of the year and proposed length of time; and organisational structure and team dynamics.
