Purpose The purpose of this procedure is to describe how incidents are to be reported, assessed for consequence, investigated and actioned. An incident is an unintended event that disturbs normal operations. This event has resulted in or has the potential to result in adverse consequences to persons, the environment, drinking water quality or a combination of these; this also includes any significant deviation from an agreement, process or procedure. Having an effective incident reporting and response process enables us to meet our legislative and performance obligations but also to ensure that we can learn from previous incidents and where appropriate identify controls to prevent reoccurrence.
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water is exposed to numerous different incidents of varying severity levels ranging from incidents that can be managed at a local level (e.g., site) to incidents that could involve a statewide response. Scope This procedure applies to all incidents, confirmed complaints and near misses including: Safety, health(well-being), environmental and water quality Process safety (plant, equipment – integrity and damage) Financial Loss (theft, fraud) Non-compliance with legal or regulatory obligations Community, social and reputational External stakeholder complaints Security (including cyber security). It covers all functions, sites and systems of work undertaken within Wannon Water by employees, contractors and the general public.
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

All incidents are to be investigated, to the extent necessary, to determine the contributing factors and root causes. From the investigation actions are to be identified which will: eliminate or minimise identified hazards or risks as far as reasonably practicable prevent recurrence or further incidents or injury improve overall system performance improve Wannon Water’s culture. Lessons learnt from incidents are to be documented and effectively communicated in a timely manner, to prevent re-occurrence and to improve our future responses. Procedure 3.1 	Immediate Action Is the Incident Scene Safe?
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

The first step in assessing any incident scene is to ensure it is safe (insofar as it is safe to do so). Upon the identification of an incident, the persons responding shall ensure that the scene is made safe and (if relevant) by controlling and containing the hazard (for example-substance spill). The relevant site emergency response plan is to be initiated for initial incident management in the event of an emergency. First Aid Individuals first on the scene of an incident involving an injury must, as far as reasonably practicable and trained to do so should provide first aid and call for assistance. Is An Emergency Response Required?
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

Does the situation constitute an emergency? An emergency response must be called if someone is seriously hurt, people are at immediate risk, or plant is endangered. These contact details, the responsibilities of the caller, and the duties of the emergency response team are to be located in site-specific Emergency Response Plan or the Emergency Management plan or other response plans. Securing the site Following an incident, the supervisor, team leader, senior person, or emergency response person should: •	Initiate the site Emergency Response Plan as required •	Where safe to do so, make the area safe and prevent escalation of the situation •	Evacuate people as necessary •	If trained provide the necessary first-aid and medical care to the injured, account for all people
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

•	Preserve the incident scene in a manner consistent with their responsibility to retain valuable information for the incident investigation. •	Notify management as required. Should Related Works be suspended? The decision to suspend works associated with the incident is the immediate responsibility of the Job Owner/Supervisor. The Job Owner/Supervisor must suspend works if: •	a serious injury or fatality has occurred •	a reportable event occurs as defined in law (see Appendix 1) •	the continuation of work may jeopardise the incident investigation. 3.2	Reporting What Must Be Reported? Any and all of the following events must be reported in Wannon Water’s Incident Reporting system: incidents resulting in injury near miss
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

drinking water quality event exceeding the appropriate regulatory limit environmental incidents breaches of trade waste agreements event(s) that may impact on plant and equipment integrity (e.g. Cyber related attacks Data Breach, loss of cardax card, Third Party Data Breach, Ransomware, Phishing, System Compromise, Denial of Service (DOS) non-compliance with procedures, and legal or regulatory obligations event(s) that may adversely impact on the community, or our reputation theft or similar misconduct security breach external stakeholder complaints that are deemed to involve abuse, harassment or incivility and impact on the health & wellbeing of our employees Who Must Report?
Incident Reporting and Response Procedure.DOCX

The responsibility to report events rests with us all. In practice, any person who knows of an event must take reasonable steps to verify that the event has been reported to the relevant line manager. To knowingly fail to report an event is regarded as a serious failure to fulfil one’s duty of care and may result in disciplinary action. Verbal Reporting to Line Management Whilst the workflow within the incident reporting system will issue emails to your Line Manager – It is good practice to also verbally notify your Line Manager or Branch Manager when an incident occurs. Lessons Learnt The Investigation lead is responsible for ensuring any lessons identified are shared with relevant teams and departments. The approval to share externally should come from the Investigation lead. Response

PURPOSE To outline the procedure covering the security of Information Technology (IT) systems at Wannon Water. The IT security model is designed to protect the information systems and information assets operated by Wannon Water by restricting access to authorised personnel and by adopting industry security best practices and standards. Wherever technically possible, Wannon Water systems will reflect the security guidelines set out in both the Victorian Protective Data Security Standards and the Australian Cyber Security Centre’s Essential 8 Cyber Security Controls. Other relevant standards and industry practices may be applied as required. SCOPE This procedure is divided into the following sections: Network security System security Equipment Security Information and Data Security
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Other Security issues The procedure covers the security practices which must be applied when using all IT systems. INSTRUCTIONS Network Security New employees Following a request from the People and Resilience team, access to the Wannon Water computer network is granted to a new employee by the IT Team.   A new Active Directory account (e.g. john.smith@wannonwater.com.au) and temporary password is created for the employee. All new employees will receive an IT induction on commencement.  This induction will include an Information Technology and Systems security component.  During this induction the employee will be shown how to change the temporary password to a private, secure password.  The procedure for network password creation and management can be found in the Password Procedure.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Typically, new employees will not be provided access to any part of Wannon Water’s IT/ IS systems until they complete this induction. Terminating employees Upon the termination of an employee, the People and Resilience Team will immediately notify the IT Team, who will immediately disable the employee’s Active Directory account and notify system owners of any non - Active Directory integrated systems to disable the employees access. Confidentiality of usernames and passwords User Names and passwords are confidential.  As such, they must not be communicated to any other person (internal or external to Wannon Water.  They must not be written down. Users other than IT team members must never knowingly login to a system as another user. Forgotten passwords
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

If forgotten, passwords can be reset by contacting the IT Team (see the Password Procedure for details). Sharing computers Employees must not use a computer that another employee is currently logged on to.  If the use of a computer is required, then the previous user must first be logged off.  The system "assumes" that the person at the keyboard is the owner of the User Name.  All session activity will be logged against that User Name and the owner will be responsible for any breaches of security. This includes connecting to Citrix sessions from a terminal, laptop or tablet device under any credentials other than the connecting users own credentials. Use of non Wannon Water issued computers
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Access to the Wannon Water computer network must only be through authorised Wannon Water equipment and procedures unless otherwise approved by the Information Technology Operations Manager. Note that this does not include publically published web services specifically provided for third party use, not does it include approved contractors using their own equipment to remotely access Wannon Water resources.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

In rare instances particular items of equipment not purchased or supported by Wannon Water may be “authorised” for use with Wannon Water information Systems, typically for brief and specific periods of use.  Examples of this include laptop or customised network devices used by consultants during maintenance or commissioning of assets.  In such instance the use of external equipment must be authorised by the Information Technology Operations Manager, or in the case of OT consultants, the Operations Digital Product Line Manager. Note that consultants may connect devices to the pre-secured “guest” WiFi network provided at Wannon Water sites. Accessing Third Party computer networks or systems
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

It is not permitted to access a Third Party network or system using Wannon Water equipment, other than to allow access to Wannon Water services – i.e.connecting to home wifi or hotel wifi to allow access to Wannon Water’s published systems. Accessing the Internet Accessing the Internet must be done using an approved method. For more information on authorised Internet use, see the Internet Usage Procedure. Third Party access to the Wannon Water network Third Party access to the Wannon Water network must follow the Remote Access (Third Parties) Procedure. Please refer to Remote access for third parties procedure for more detail. System Security
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

All systems (e.g. Finance One, Aquarate, Conquest, Fulcrum, Records Manager, Clear SCADA, etc…) have an information system administrator and associated information asset steward Note in some instances the same officer fills both the roles of information system administrator and information asset steward. As per the Information Access Procedure, information asset stewards are accountable for ensuring appropriate access is granted to end users. Information system administrators are responsible for implementing and maintaining security access as approved by information asset stewards. Security access to systems will be routinely reviewed. System User Name and password maintenance
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Where no direct Active Directory integration exists, the information system administrator is responsible for establishing new User Names for the relevant application, and setting standard passwords.  It is the employee’s responsibility to reset the standard password to one that only they know.  Assistance with this process can be provided by the information system administrator. The information system administrator is responsible for maintaining User Names for the relevant application under the authorisation of the relevant information asset steward.  Requests for enhanced system privileges must be made to the information asset steward, and will be implemented by the appropriate system administrator(s). Multi Factor authentication
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Where ever possible, and particularly for externally facing systems, multi factor authentication (i.e. a second form of authentication) will be used. The particular MFA method used by a specific information system can be either passive (i.e. a registered signed certificate) or active (i.e. a challenge – response mechanism) and will be determined by the Information Technology Operations Manager. Note that a challenge – response method is preferred for any external facing information system. Equipment Security Locking the computer When an employee leaves their desk for any period of time, it is important that they lock the computer (Press and hold the Window “Start” button and then press “L”). This will also occur automatically after 10 minutes of inactivity.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

This also applies to all non windows devices issued by Wannon Water, including tablets and smartphones. Shutting down the computer When an employee leaves their place of work for the day, they must shut down their computer (click Start, then Shutdown, then OK). Tablet devices and smartphones must be appropriately ‘screen locked’ when not in use. Laptop and tablet security Laptops are highly portable.  Do not leave a laptop unattended outside of a Wannon Water location (see the Portable Computer Procedure). If a laptop or tablet device is left unattended in a vehicle the laptop or tablet device must be secured out of plain sight, such as underneath the seats, in the glove compartment etc.  The vehicle must also be securely parked and locked at all times when unattended.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

If a laptop or tablet device is misplaced or believed stolen it must be reported to the IT team as soon as is practical.  Many devices can be remote located or remote wiped, greatly minimising the potential security impact of any loss. Smartphone or Smart Device security Smartphones and other smart devices are increasingly powerful tools and are increasingly used as a tool for business.  As a result, a smartphone typically contains potentially valuable business data or access to business data on it, not the least being real time email access.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water employees issued a corporate smartphone are encouraged to maintain a high degree of awareness of their smartphone.  As with laptop and tablet devices, a smartphone is a highly desirable asset and must not be left unattended.  Smartphones must be locked at all times when not in use, and should not be connected to unsolicited public WIFI networks. When left in a vehicle, the smartphone must not be left in public view (i.e. left in the phone cradle) and the vehicle must be locked and secured if left unattended.  This includes brief stops such as in petrol stations.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

If a smartphone or other smart device is believed lost or stolen the responsible officer must report the loss to the IT team as soon as is practically possible.  As with laptops and tablets, many smartphones or devices can be remotely located and / or wiped, significantly reducing the security risk to Wannon Water. Information (Data) Security Intellectual Property Information contained within any Wannon Water system is viewed as Wannon Water property. Therefore, any unauthorised copying or transmission of Information may be seen as theft and subject to the Consequences of Employee Misconduct procedure.  See the Intellectual Property Procedure. Information transfer /extraction
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

The transfer of or extraction of any information must be approved by the appropriate information asset steward(s).  This includes the extraction of Wannon Water information or data for third party reporting uses. The usage of privately owned data storage devices within Wannon Water systems, to remove data or information from corporate repositories, is prohibited. Other security issues Security holes or flaws If employees find a possible security hole or flaw on any Wannon Water computer system or procedure, they are encouraged to immediately report it to the Information Technology team, the Information Security Manager or to their supervisor, either directly or via RiskWare. Viruses
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

If employees transfer a file from a USB Memory Stick to the network (G, H drive), then this file must be scanned by the employee using the anti-virus software installed on their computer.  For assistance, please contact IT. System Patching Vendors constantly release patches and system upgrades that are designed to mitigate security vulnerabilities.  These patches can range from simple, quick to apply code updates to large, complex version upgrades. It is the responsibility of system administrators to ensure the systems they administer are patched to an appropriate security level to minimise cyber risk to Wannon Water. Note that patching of applications will typically fall under the change and configuration management framework currently being rolled out by Wannon Water. Procedure Breaches
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Procedure breaches will be reported to Wannon Water’s CIO and the Cyber Resilience Working Group and can be subject to Wannon Water's Consequences of Employee Misconduct procedure. Breaches of this procedure will be recorded and managed as security incidents within RiskWare, Wannon Water’s incident management tool. Exclusions On the rare occasions, due to operational support requirements, the Information Technology or Operational Technology team may be required to use a system logged in as another user. From time to time it may also be necessary for a system administrator or information asset steward to login to a discrete system as a system user.  These instances should be kept to a minimum and be used purely for system testing and troubleshooting and never for operational use.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

RESPONSIBILITY The CIO is accountable for this procedure. The Information Security Manager is responsible for maintaining this procedure and making employees aware of any changes to it. The Information Technology Operations Manager is responsible for the application of this procedure Anyone with access to the Wannon Water computer network is responsible for abiding by this procedure. As part of the Wannon Water induction program, employees will be required to sign a document, indicating that they have read, understood and will abide by the requirements of this procedure. DEFINITIONS Information Technology (IT) team The Information Technology team is contactable on extension 6777. System administrators
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

A system administrator or owner is a Wannon Water officer with responsibility for the management of a particular system.  Such management typically includes day to day system support and operational performance management, and in some cases system upgrades. Typically system administrators have higher security access levels than operational users to those systems. A system administrators authority will typically only extend to the discreet application they manage, in some cases however certain systems may be linked, meaning a system administrator may have higher security access to a number of systems, or a number of system administrators may have overlapping access to a set of systems.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Typically an information system administrator will manage an information system holding or processing information assets (i.e. as ‘infrastructure’). Information asset stewards An information asset steward is an officer assigned by the information asset owner to be responsible for managing the information asset on a day to day basis. The Information Steward guides how the information is managed, protected and used on behalf of the owner and defines and enforces rules for the information asset. Wannon Water computer network The Wannon Water computer network includes: Site Local Area Network, connecting computers and devices within a specific location, Wide Area Network, connecting Wannon Water sites, Remote Access users – those mobile users connecting to Wannon Water services remotely
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Cloud and SAAS services provided for users by Wannon Water.  Examples of these are the RiskWare and Azure platforms currently used by Wannon Water. SCADA specific networks such as profibus, BacNet or ModBus connections are however excluded from this definition and deemed to be a part of the SCADA ‘system’ User Names and passwords User Names uniquely identify user principles to information system and enable access to information assets.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water requires user principles to be wherever possible natural persons – shared or generic usernames are not to be used. The user principal assigned a username –i.e. the ‘person’ the username is assigned to – is accountable for that username and all activity carried out under that username. In the majority of cases, usernames will be generated in Active Directory and imported into other applications.
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Passwords authenticate user principals identified by a User Name against an Information system.  The default authentication method to be used by Wannon Water is a challenge – response mechanism using a password.  All usernames will have an associated password – there will be no instances of blank passwords.  All passwords must be kept confidential and adhere to the requirements of the Password Policy  Note that certain access may require the use of a second form of authentication in the form of a token or code as appropriate. Active Directory integration
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Active Directory integration refers to an information system drawing User Names and Passwords for an account from Active Directory.  Wherever possible Active Directory integration should be used.  This centralises the creation and administration of User Names and Passwords in Active Directory. Authorised Wannon Water equipment and procedures All equipment which has been purchased and installed by the IT Team is classified as “authorised”. Refer to the computer user’s procedure All procedures that are located in SharePoint and are not in a ‘Draft’ status are classified as “authorised”. External computer systems
Information Technology Security Procedure.DOCX

Any computer system which is not directly connected to the Wannon Water network is classified as “external”.  For example, vendors, customers, other water authorities may have a network which is classified as external. IT Systems This includes the network, applications, data and all other infrastructure, including Wannon Water operated SAAS and cloud platforms. Third Party A Third Party is a non Wannon Water individual, group, organisation or company. Some Third Parties are contracted to provide support to various IT systems. Depending on the business criticality of the system that they support, Third Parties will be classified as either Tier 1 suppliers or Tier 2 suppliers. VPDSS

PURPOSE To outline the procedure and guidelines for the proper and approved use of the Internet connection at Wannon Water. SCOPE This procedure covers use of the Internet. INSTRUCTIONS Acceptable Use Use of the Internet by employees is permitted and encouraged where such use is suitable for business purposes and supports the mission and objectives of Wannon Water.  The Internet is to be used in a manner that is consistent with Wannon Water’s professional standards of business conduct.
Internet Usage Procedure.DOCX

Occasional personal use is permitted but remains subject to this procedure, with the additional limitation that restricts the downloading of large sized files (ie downloads should be less than 10 MB).  Occasional personal use must occur outside normal working hours.  Lunch time private use is permitted for viewing Internet information (ie no file downloading), so as to ensure optimal network response times for work purposes. Unacceptable Use The following use of the Internet is not allowable, at any time: Accessing the Internet via another employee's account. Viewing or downloading  (see section 3 for definitions of “offensive or illegal material”). Usage which causes disruption to the network or other employees. Commercial activities of a personal nature.
Internet Usage Procedure.DOCX

Frequent visits to, or large downloads from, non-business related web sites, newsgroups and chat rooms. Downloading large files (10MB or larger).  If such a download is required for business purposes, then please send a request to the IT department. Uploading, downloading or otherwise transmitting commercial software or copyrighted material in violation of its copyright. Using Wannon Water network passwords for external web sites. Accessing sites for the purposes of gambling. Monitoring Internet Usage Internet usage can be monitored, with activity reports being sent to managers, upon a formal request to the BMKT from either the Managing Director, the relevant General Manager or the relevant Branch Manager.  Such a request must include: The requestor’s name, The date of request,
Internet Usage Procedure.DOCX

Details of the activity being sought, Details of why this information is being sought The BMKT will delegate responsibility for completing the request to an IT Officer, who will then access the internet usage data and return it directly to the BMKT.  The BMKT will then assess the data in a meeting with the requesting manager.  The internet usage data will be made available to the manager to take whatever action they deem appropriate. At all times, the request itself and the internet usage data will remain confidential. This is the only time that any member of the IT team shall be authorised to access internet usage data.

Filtering software has been installed which has the option of preventing access to certain categories of site (eg sites that may contain offensive material, security threats, etc). Purpose To provide clear, consistent and effective media and social media messaging that helps enhance our reputation and improve customer perceptions of the value we provide to our entire community. Scope The procedure applies to the entire organisation, but management of media and social media is only to be implemented by the Communications & Engagement Branch. Procedure Media Releases and Enquiries All media releases are formal Wannon Water statements and will be prepared by the Communications & Engagement Branch.
Media and Social Media Management Procedure.DOCX

The only authorised media spokespersons are the Managing Director, Chair, Branch Manager Communications & Engagement and the Media & Communications Coordinator. In some circumstances, the Executive Team or employees with specific knowledge regarding an innovation or project may act as spokespersons when co-ordinated by the Media & Communications Coordinator. Final media releases will be distributed to relevant media organisations and published on the Wannon Water corporate website and in the Company News section of WaterSHED. They will also be emailed to Board Directors.
Media and Social Media Management Procedure.DOCX

All media enquiries should come directly to the Media & Communications Coordinator via mobile phone (0437 797 117) or email. In the coordinator’s  absence, enquiries should be directed to the Branch Manager Communications & Engagement. Media Approvals The Communications & Engagement Branch will liaise with the relevant Wannon Water employees to prepare the media release or media response. In cases where there is a third party involved or mentioned (e.g. a local council or CMA), the media release or response will be sent to that organisation for feedback and approval. Final media releases and responses must receive approval from the Managing Director, the Acting Managing Director (in the Managing Director’s absence), or the Board Chair (in the absence of a Managing Director).

No media releases or responses are to be issued without this approval. Note: DELWP and/or the Minister’s office may request final approval of media releases and responses. User Guide (as packaged with the phone) Upon receipt of a new mobile phone, it is strongly recommended that the employee familiarise themselves with the phone’s features by reading the accompanying user guide. No replacement phone will be issued without a corresponding RiskWare incident being raised, including the completion of the incident form. The installation and use of apps for personal purposes should be kept to a minimum. The installation and use of apps should take into account the . Calls made outside of business hours when an employee is not on standby or on call. Calls with a duration of longer than five (5) minutes. Calls to interstate numbers. Charges or fees for any activity not considered reasonable for the operation of the employee’s role. Use of Mobile Phones in Vehicles Precautionary Principle The use of a mobile phone when in control of a vehicle elevates the risk of a serious motor vehicle incident. There are laws that control the use of a mobile phone by a driver. Wannon Water also makes rules above and beyond the law to provide additional safety.
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water urges drivers to comply with the law and rules, and also urges drivers to be cautious and risk aware. For further information refer to: Victoria Road Safety Rules (Law) The Victoria law is specified in Section 300 Use of Mobile Phones of the Victorian ,  which is amended with . A summary of the above section in relation to mobile phone use by a driver of a vehicle is as follows: Learner and probationary drivers are not permitted to use a mobile phone at all while driving. Texting, email, video calls or such communication are not permitted.
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

A driver may make and receive a phone call, perform an audio function, or use the mobile phone as a navigational aid while driving provided the phone is secured in a mounting affixed to the vehicle which is commercially designed, manufactured and installed according to manufacturer instructions. A driver may use an un-affixed mobile phone while driving, to make and receive a phone call, perform an audio function, or use the phone as a navigational aid as long as they do not touch the phone in any way (“touching the phone” includes resting the phone on the driver’s lap).
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

A driver is deemed to be “driving” even when the vehicle is stationary. The driver is deemed to be no longer “driving” when the vehicle is pulled off the road and parked safely. There are other laws that may be applied by the Police such as dangerous driving laws. Victoria Police Advice The Victoria Police are responsible for administering the Victorian Road Safety Rules. The Victoria Police advises the following on its web site: “Using a mobile phone whilst driving distracts your attention from the road and prevents you from maintaining proper control of your vehicle. Due to this, using a hand-held mobile phone whilst driving is illegal and attracts a significant fine and three demerit points.
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

You do not need to be talking on the phone to be breaking the law. Whilst driving, it is illegal to: Talk Send or receive text messages Play phone-based games Take photos. It is also illegal to perform these activities when your vehicle is stopped but not parked, such as when waiting at traffic lights. If your phone rings or you need to send a message while driving, pull over and park safely and legally before answering it. It is illegal to use a hands-free phone whilst driving if it causes you to lose proper control of your vehicle. The penalty is a significant fine and demerit points.
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

Although a hands-free device can reduce the physical effort to make and receive calls, it does not necessarily make phone use safer while driving. Consider the following suggestions if you must talk on a hands-free phone whilst driving: Make sure the hands-free function is set up and working before you start driving. Keep conversations short. Do not engage in complex or emotional conversations. Explain to your caller that you are driving and arrange a better time to speak with them. If it is distracting you from driving, end the call.” Wannon Water’s Position A driver of a Wannon Water vehicle must comply with relevant road laws in relation to using a mobile phone and comply with the Victoria Police Advice set out above.
Mobile Phone Procedure.DOCX

It is recommended that a driver of a Wannon Water vehicle pull over and park the vehicle in a safe location to initiate, receive or engage in a phone call, because this is the safest method to communicate. Procurement decisions will balance the operational needs of the business with the preference to have the leading vehicles available in regards to the safety of employees and environmental sustainability Procurement and disposal will be efficient and follow a transparent process Vehicles will be well maintained so as to ensure safe and efficient motoring; and Employees understand their responsibilities in relation to the operation of Wannon Water vehicles. Wannon Water has an obligation to provide a safe workplace under the Occupational Health & Safety Act 2004.  Motor vehicles are included as a workplace within this Act. In meeting this obligation, Wannon Water has in place management systems that relate to the procurement, disposal, maintenance and operation of motor vehicles which aim to ensure that all Wannon Water motor vehicles are safe workplaces for all employees and other persons.  This Procedure is part of this management system and sets out Wannon Water’s expectations of employees and other persons for the operation of Wannon Water motor vehicles. MAINTENANCE

All motor vehicles are to be serviced in accordance with manufacturer’s specifications.  Vehicle custodians will ensure that services are completed in a timely manner. Vehicle custodians should be vigilant about vehicle maintenance at all times. In instances of emergency Where transportation of members of the public or other stakeholders is in the best interests of Wannon Water Where an employee is rostered on standby and has a Commuter Use Agreement and is wearing PPE ready to attend a worksite should an after-hours call out occur; Where a motor vehicle is provided for Private Use; and Any other circumstance where approval of a General Manager is obtained in advance. Purpose Wannon Water is committed to providing appropriate support and assistance to employees who suffer a non-work-related injury, illness, or medical condition; this procedure defines the process when such an event occurs. Wannon Water recognises there are benefits to supporting an employee to return to work early when recovering from an illness or injury. Scope This procedure aims to outline the process for managing the return to work for an employee, with a non-work-related injury or illness. It does not apply to employees who suffer a workplace injury or illness. Where an employee suffers a workplace injury or illness, they should refer to the . Procedure
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

The circumstances of non-work-related injuries and illness vary widely and as such our approach to managing the return to work for employees will vary.  We outline the requirements for differing circumstances below: An employee will require a medical clearance and a return-to-work plan prior to recommencing work when: The employee is absent from work due to a more serious non-work-related injury or illness includes: where there is an identified risk of acerbating the injury by returning to the workplace. an employee has surgery and is on leave for longer than 1 week an employee provides a medical certificate for an absence greater than ten consecutive working days an employee provides a medical certificate advising restrictions for work, either on hours or duties for any length of time
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

where an employee or their line manager raises any concerns about an employee’s capacity to perform the inherent requirements of their role, due to non-work-related injury or illness. An employee may not require a medical clearance or return to work plan when: The employee is absent from work due to a minor non-work-related injury or illness, where returning to work: does not pose a risk of pose a risk of re-injury, aggravation of a pre-existing medical condition the risk of re-injury or aggravation to the employee’s injury or illness is assessed as being ‘low.’ Managers should refer ‘’ for further guidance in assessing the risk consideration for both the likelihood of re-injury or aggravation and the consequences for further injury or illness
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

does not pose a risk to the health and safety of others where an employee or their line manager agree there are no concerns about an employee’s capacity to perform the inherent requirements of their role, due to non-work-related injury or illness. Returning to work earlier than your medical certificate outlines for minor injuries and illnesses
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

The Manager People and Wellbeing in conjunction with the appropriate Branch Manager have discretion to permit an employee to return to work whilst a medical certificate is still valid if the employee has recovered from a minor injury or illness.  In this situation a medical clearance will not be required.  The line manager and employee must both agree that the employee has adequately recovered to undertake the inherent requirements of their role without modifications being required. If at any time an employee presents to work with any obvious medical condition that could be exacerbated by their attendance at work, the line manager must instruct the employee to cease work until the risk can be formally assessed and mitigated. When you don’t need a Return-to-Work Plan (RTWP)
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

Where an employee provides medical information with full clearance to return to work to their pre-injury or illness hours and duties, without restrictions, a RTWP is not required. Return to work discussions Where an employee is absent from work due to a more serious non-work-related injury or illness, the Return-to-Work Coordinator (RTWC) is to be advised as soon as possible and is to be consulted before the employee returns to work. The primary goal of a RTWP is to return an employee to pre-injury duties of their substantive position. Where an employee is unable temporarily resume full duties, a RTWP may be developed to facilitate an early return to work as a short-term arrangement.
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

Where Wannon Water receives medical information recommending modified temporary arrangements to support an employee’s return to work, a range of adjustments may be considered on a case-by-case scenario, including: implementing flexible work arrangements such as working from home or flexible start/finish times modified duties, where the employee performs all usual tasks of their position but in a different way to comply with medical restrictions and to minimise risk to their health and safety reduced or alternative duties, where the employee performs a portion of usual duties, or different duties; compatible with their skills and experience, and complying with medical restrictions providing equipment or aids to assist the employee to perform their duties
Non Work Related Illness or Injury Management Procedure.DOCX

providing access to services to assist the employee to undertake their duties, for example providing time and access to Wannon Water’s Employee Assistance Program. Work from home arrangements may be considered for non-work-related injury or illness situations consistent with the . The RTWP should include strategies to increase work capacity to enable a gradual return to substantive duties. When the employee has recovered from their injury or illness, and indicates they have the capacity for a full return to substantive duties, a short period of monitoring may be required to ensure the return to work is sustainable and that no further intervention is required. Before the employee can return to work, a manager will review and assess if there any health and safety risks. There should already be control measures in place for general risks, so this assessment only needs to focus on extra risks relating to supporting the employee’s return to work, their injury or illness and substantive duties. In assessing the risk to health and safety, managers should identify and mitigate any hazards or risks that an employee may face when returning to work after an extended absence due to a non-work-related injury or illness. Factors that should be considered, may include but not limited to: barriers to the employee working the work environment the use of work equipment the use of or exposure to dangerous substances or chemicals

the work activity, including interaction with other people the employee – if the condition or medication may affect their behaviour emergencies, standby or additional hours – suitability of the employee to undertake such duties whilst recovering. Decision Making The Manager People & Wellbeing and the appropriate Branch Manager will make the decision to allow or decline a RTWP for non-work-related injury or illness, based on sound risk management principles following the assessment, regarding all available information.

Wannon Water is not obligated to provide employment where an employee’s non-work-related injury/illness prevents them from performing their substantive duties on a long term or permanent basis. Purpose Consistent with the Zero Harm Policy, Wannon Water is committed to providing a working environment that ensures the physical, mental, and social safety of all employees. Recognising that, despite best efforts, injuries and illnesses may still occur, the Occupational Rehabilitation Procedure outlines Wannon Water's commitment to fulfilling its obligation to make all practicable efforts to support employees in staying at work or returning to work after an injury or illness resulting from their employment. Scope This procedure has been developed to meet the legislative requirements as per the Workplace Injury Rehabilitation Act 2013 and amendments and relates only to injuries or illnesses covered by an accepted WorkCover claim. Procedure When a Work-Related Injury or Illness Occurs
Occupational Rehabilitation Procedure.DOCX

Wannon Water (the employer) will: Ensure an incident report in Riskware has been completed in relation to the injury, and conduct an investigation where required. Provide the injured employee with first aid where appropriate and/or medical treatment as soon as possible. Provide information on the WorkCover claim process and provide the employee claim forms should the employee wish to lodge a claim. Notify its workers compensation insurance provider of any serious injury, being an injury where the employee is unlikely to return to their pre-injury duties for a period of more than 7 days (note: best practice)
Occupational Rehabilitation Procedure.DOCX

Notify WorkSafe Victoria, of any serious workplaces incidents considered to be a ‘notifiable incident’ in adherence with legislative timeframes and requirements as per the Occupational Health and Safety Act 2004 A Return to Work Coordinator will contact the injured employee as soon as possible. The Return to Work Coordinator will ensure access to appropriate treatment and obtain details of the extent of any capacity for work. The employee will: Report the incident to the local supervisor at the first available opportunity and complete an incident report within Riskware. Depending on the injury, an employee may require the supervisor or another employee onsite to complete the incident report on their behalf. Make reasonable efforts to return to work with their employer
Occupational Rehabilitation Procedure.DOCX

Make reasonable efforts to actively participate and cooperate in planning for return to work Actively use an occupational rehabilitation service if provided, and cooperate with the provider of that service Actively participate and cooperate in assessments of their capacity for work, rehabilitation progress or future employment prospects Actively participate and cooperate in an interview for the purpose of enhancing their return-to-work opportunities, if requested to do so If unable to perform their normal duties due to a work-related injury or illness, the employee must notify the Return to Work Coordinator and management and provide a medical certificate advising of incapacity. Below are some tips to keep in mind when making online purchases using the corporate cards: 1. Ensure that you are confident that you are using a reputable company with a proven track record. Contact the provider prior to the transaction to confirm. 2. Always ensure that you use a ‘https’ website with a padlock symbol in the right hand side of the address bar. The ‘s’ shows that the site is using an encryption system, scrambling your information and making it hard for hackers to follow your details. 3. Do not use your phone or mobile device when making online purchases as the security software may not be up to date and you may be using unsecured public Wi-Fi.
Online Purchase Guidelines for Corporate Credit Card Holders.DOCX

4. Do use an online payment services (such as PayPal) if available. When you have an account, it hides your credit card details from the store/seller which insures extra protection against hackers. You can also be refunded with their Buyer Protection guarantee. 5. Try to type in the URL for the retailer rather than ‘googling’ the store as this will reduce the risk of clicking on a fraudulent link from a google search. 6. If the website looks outdated, has errors or just ‘doesn’t look right’, trust your instincts and don’t use it. Never click on links in emails and always open a new browser and go to the main site from there not via the link. 7. Regularly check transactions on your card and contact the bank if there are any unusual transactions.
Online Purchase Guidelines for Corporate Credit Card Holders.DOCX

8. Be mindful of making payments in a pop-up window. If a pop-up is required, the payment instructions should tell you that you will be routed to a third party (like PayPal) to process the payment. Always check the pop-up.

PURPOSE To assist with recording and reporting on Opex Projects within Enterprise Budgeting (EB) and it the OP Budget ledger. SCOPE This procedure applied to the Finance & Regulation team (specifically the Management Accountant) and the Asset Creation team (specifically BM Asset Creation) INSTRUCTIONS The Corporate Plan is developed in the latter months of the financial year and during this process the budget is set for the next year’s Opex projects. These projects are aligned with the Pricing Submission where possible and their budget amounts are escalated to the dollars of the day. The Opex project list is used to input the Opex projects into EB for the relevant financial year at the original amount and then automatically escalated to the dollars of the day.
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

BM Asset Creation will then allocate the cash flow timing of budget expenditure in EB. This information is then used to journal the budget figures into the OP Ledger with the correct timings. An XLOne report has been created to lookup the figures in the OP Budget Ledger and compare them to the cash flow figures in EB. This is run every month and if there are significant variances the OP Budget Ledger is updated to ensure accurate budget/actual reporting to the board. Using Enterprise Budgeting The current (2018 – 2023) Pricing Submission Project Model is called ‘PROJECT1819’
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

The module is broken into each year of the Pricing Submission in tabs across the top and a separate tab for ‘Escalation Rates’ and ‘Attachments’. The projects are also categorised into Capex and Opex, of which this procedure is focussed on Opex projects only. To add a new project: Steps 1-7 below are only required is the project is not included in any year of the program. If you need to add a project into a new year (project already exists in another year) you can start at step 8. The following describes the process to add a new project into the model: Firstly you need to ensure that the project has been created in both the financial and projects modules. Before entering the project into the program (in the year it is required) a new project account needs to be set up.
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

To begin this process select the ‘New account’ option Now the project account needs to be created. This is done by selecting the project code, the project function and then the location. NOTE: ensure that you have the correct function and location for that project by checking in ‘WRW Contract/Project Manager Module. Under ‘Projects List’ tab, search for the project number, click into the project and scroll to the bottom of the details and you will find the financial integration with the allocated function and location. If the account has been set up correctly you will see the status displays ‘Will Be Added’.
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

If there is more than one project to be added the above steps can be repeated until all new projects accounts have been added. Please note that it is necessary that you note the location code used for each project as this information will be required later in the process. Once all new project accounts have been updated you need to select Save. After saving you need to select Retrieve to refresh the data. The projects can now be entered into the worksheet. To add a project into the worksheet, ensure that you have the correct year’s tab open. At the bottom of the project list there will be a blank row that you can use to enter new project lines. The project number can be typed into the project cell or it can be selected from the drop down list.
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

The location code can be typed into the cell or selected form the drop down list. Please note that the location code MUST match the location code used when creating the project account. All other information in the project fields should be completed as appropriate. If the project is being added into a new year and exists already in another year, you need to ensure where relevant the information is consistent. Once all of the required information is entered the worksheet should be saved by selecting ‘Save’ under ‘Actions to Perform’ in the top left of the window. During the year:
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

Throughout the year new projects will be added for unexpected ‘incidents’ to enable clear tracking of costs. These are ‘Non-Budgeted’ projects and are allocated to the Risk and Resilience team with SVR as the project manager. There may also be wholly externally funded projects that need to be added. We do not record ‘Non-Budgeted’ or ‘Externally Funded’ in the OP budget ledger. An XLOne report () has been written to compare the cash flows of the projects in EB with the period’s allocated budget in the OP budget ledger. This report excludes any ‘Non-Budgeted’ and ‘Externally Funded’ projects. This report is run as a part of the end of month process. Notes:
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

Before entering the budget amounts into EB at the start of the year ensure that the escalation rate for that year has been updated. It sits at 4.1000 until Simon updates it. This will allow you to ‘de-escalate’ the project amount from the Corporate Plan Opex project list to then make sure that when the amounts in EB are automatically escalated they match the Corporate Plan. When filling out the ‘Department Responsible’ and ‘Project Manager’ fields, ensure that you don’t make a typo as this information is used by Brad for reporting. Also if you are adding a new ‘Project Manager’ let brad know so he can update his reports.
Opex Projects Budget Allocations in Enterprise Budgeting and the Ledger.DOCX

When monitoring the variances between EB and the ledger ensure that you journal any material timing changes at the end of each quarter. The materiality threshold has not yet been set for this. RESPONSIBILITY Management Accountant (Mel Maher): To update all projects at the start of the year and add any new projects during the year. To ensure that the OP Budget Ledger loaded with budgets at the start of the year and the timing is adjusted during the year if required. MB Asset Creation (Simon Perrin): To allocate the cash flows at the beginning of the year. To monitor the progress of projects during the year and amend cash flows in EB if required. Wannon Water   |   Our Voice Guide   |   Jan 2023   |   PAGE 14 Getting the basics right - Numbers and figures Numbers Generally, the numbers one to nine are spelt out, and 10 and above are written as numerals e.g. We have five projects planned that will benefit 11 towns.

Note: This section does not apply to tables, lists and charts in documents such as financial reports where numerals can be used Wannon Water   |   Our Voice Guide   |   Jan 2023   |   PAGE 15 Getting the basics right - Apostrophes Contractions Contractions are used when two words are combined to sound more casual or informal. The apostrophe is always placed where the letter/s have been removed. Some common examples are: • couldn't - could not • doesn't - does not • don't - do not
Our Voice Guide - January 2023.pdf

• he'll - he will • I'd - I would • I'll - I will • I'm - I am • isn't - is not • it's - it is OR it has • she'd - she would • we're  - we are • who's - who is • you'll - you will • you're  - you are.Possession Possessive apostrophes show that a thing (a noun) belongs or is related to someone or something else. Singular nouns and names When the noun is singular, add an apostrophe plus 's' e.g:  Wannon Water's pipeline, one week's notice. When a singular noun already ends in 's', add an apostrophe plus another 's' (the general rule is you should write it as you say it) e.g: James's pen. Plural nouns For plural nouns that end with an 's', add an apostrophe AFTER the 's'. For example if there is more than one water authority or week e.g:  The water authorities' pipelines, two weeks' notice.

For plural nouns that don't end with an 's' (e.g. children, men and women), add an apostrophe BEFORE the 's' e.g: The children's poster competition, International Women's Day.It’s vs its One of the most common apostrophe mistakes is placing an apostrophe in the word ITS to show something belongs to IT. But this rule doesn’t apply to pronouns – its, yours, his, hers, ours, theirs. As outlined, it’s is always a contraction of 'it is' or 'it has'. Its describes something that belongs to it e.g: The committee elected its president, the vehicle had its service. The easiest way to remember this rule is to read it back to yourself. The committee elected it's president effectively reads the committee elected it is president, which doesn't make sense. When NOT to use an apostrophe
Our Voice Guide - January 2023.pdf

Don't use an apostrophe just because a word is plural e.g. reports (not report's), USBs  (not USB's), 1990s  (not 1990's). However, if you are referring to something that belongs to a decade, add an apostrophe e.g. the 1990s' pipeline . Standalone words in everyday use, like ‘old’ and ‘young’, can carry

bias or unintended subtext. Words that carry stereotypes, for example ‘elderly’, are not acceptable. When an age or age range is relevant to a fact, you can use the term ‘people’ with the age reference e.g.  Survey data showed people aged 15 to 17 years were the highest proportion of internet users.Gender and sexual diversity Inclusive language conveys gender equality and is gender neutral. Respect peoples’ preferences around gender and sexual identity with pronoun choice, job titles and personal titles. Do not default to a generic gendered pronoun like 'he' or 'she' to talk about a generic person. Instead, use 'they', 'their' and 'them' to refer to singular subjects as this allows you to speak to a broader audience of men, women, and other identifying genders.

Unless gender is relevant, always use gender- neutral words rather than gender-specific ones. For example, use 'workforce' instead of 'manpower', 'artificial' instead of 'man made', and 'access point' rather than 'manhole'. Don’t ask for a preferred title (e.g. Mr, Mrs, Ms) or gender identity in a form or survey unless you specifically need to collect this information. On a side note, when giving addressing a group, avoid the term "ladies and gentlemen". Instead, simply use 'good morning', 'good afternoon' or 'welcome everyone' which are all inclusive.People with a disability Disability does not define people. Use inclusive language that respects diversity e.g: person with disability  (NOT disabled person), person who is deaf or hard of hearing  (NOT
Our Voice Guide - January 2023.pdf

deaf person), person who is blind or has low vision  (NOT blind person). Cultural and linguistic diversity Australians have different cultural backgrounds and speak many languages. Use inclusive language that respects this diversity. You can use the general term ‘multicultural communities’ to write about people from different cultural backgrounds. When you ask people their name, don’t ask for ‘Christian name’, ‘first name’, ‘forename’ or ‘surname’. These terms all take for granted the European conventions and order of names. Purpose The purpose of this procedure is to outline how to make a payment of PAYG Withholding tax to the Australian Taxation Office on a fortnightly basis. Scope This procedure is applicable to the Payroll Coordinator (and the Payroll Officer, in the Coordinators absence), who holds the responsibility for arranging the payment of PAYG Withholding Tax to the Australian Taxation Office on a fortnightly basis. Procedure An Internal Tax Invoice has to be raised at end of each fortnightly payroll period. Open Watershed –> under Applications –> click on eFORMS. Select Internal Tax Invoice. Claim details = GST Exempt. Payment Method – leave blank. Claim Type – select PAYG Withholding Tax from the drop down arrow – this will prefill Payee Details.

Under Particulars – The detail: PAYG Withholding Tax F/E will default automatically, update the end of the detail to include the F/E date – Payroll, the ledger code will default automatically to natural account 607, and enter the dollar ($) amount. Confirm the Total dollar ($) amount balances in full. Under Upload Attachments – Click on the Upload button to upload the signatured and dated Pay Summary Report(s) PDF attachment(s), which are produced as part of each payroll period. Purpose This policy is designed to ensure the protection of the corporation's physical assets and the safety of its employees, contractors, and visitors. Scope This policy applies to all employees. This policy applies to all facilities and locations owned or leased by the corporation and includes co-hosted sites where Wannon Water equipment is located on third party premises. Policy statement Wannon Water shall implement the following physical security measures to safeguard its assets and personnel: Access Control Access to the corporation's facilities shall be controlled and where possible monitored to prevent unauthorised access. Access control measures include: Physical barriers, such as fences and gates as defined in the Site Security Standards,
Physical Security Policy.docx

Where assets are mounted inside cabinets or enclosures, these cabinets or enclosures be security rated Security coded locks and padlocks on all doors, gates and fences Electronic access control systems All visitors shall be required to sign in and out of the facility, and will be supervised by an authorised employee or contractor. Access will be granted acording to the principles of Least Access and Zero Trust.  Access to sensitive areas, such as control rooms and data centers, shall be restricted to authorised personnel only.
Physical Security Policy.docx

Remote Assets: Where a Wannon Water asset or assets are contained remotely within a third party’s asset, that Wannon Water asset must be secured against unuathorised access.  This will at a minimum include a security rated cabinet and lock. Appropriate intrusion detection alarming will be fitted wherever possible. Security Cameras: The corporation shall install and maintain a video surveillance system to monitor all entry and exit points, as well as other critical areas. All recorded footage shall be stored securely. Access to recorded footage will be by authorised officers only, with all access being logged. Note that Security Cameras are considered a passive security control and will only be used in addition to appropriate access controls.
Physical Security Policy.docx

Alarm Systems: The corporation shall install and maintain intrustion detection systems to detect any unauthorised access or intrusion into its facilities. These systems shall be monitored by authorised personel or contractors. Lighting: All facilities and their surroundings shall be adequately lit to deter intruders and enhance visibility and safety of personell during night time operations Security lighting where fitted will comply with relevant Australian Standards such as AS2293:1:2018 and the Australian Government  .
Physical Security Policy.docx

Key / Electronic Token Control: Keys and electronic tokens to the corporation's facilities shall be issued only to authorised personnel, and their distribution shall be documented and monitored. Keys shall be returned when no longer needed or when an employee or contractor leaves the corporation. Electronic tokens will be immediately disabled and then returned when access is no longer required. Lost keys or tokens will be reported immediately. Following the concepts of least access and zero trust, keys and tokens with the least access level required by personell or contractors will be issued – that is, master keys will not be issued. Keys or tokens issued to contractors will be counter authorised by an appropriate officer authorising the works requiring access.
Physical Security Policy.docx

Electronic tokens issued to contractors will be pre-programmed to expire at the end of an authorised period of access. Personnel Training: All employees, contractors, and visitors shall be trained in the corporation's physical security policies and procedures. This includes how to respond to emergencies, how to report suspicious activities, and how to use access control systems. Contractor Management: The corporation shall ensure that all contractors hired to perform work on its facilities comply with its physical security policies and procedures.  All contractors will be managed via Wannon Waters Contractor Management System.
Physical Security Policy.docx

Physical Security Risk Assessment: The corporation shall conduct periodic physical security risk assessments to identify vulnerabilities and implement appropriate measures to mitigate the identified risks. Patrol and Site Monitoring: The authority will routinely patrol and monitor physical security systems for sites deemed necessary.  This may take the form of formal security patrols, routine site visits by officers, or remote monitoring via electronic systems. Breach of Policy: Any detected breach of policy will be recorded as an incident in the Authority’s risk and incident management system.  Breaches will be investigated following standard Wannon Water practices.  Where appropriate, breaches will be reported to appropriate authorities.
Physical Security Policy.docx

This policy shall be reviewed and updated periodically to ensure its effectiveness. The corporation shall continuously strive to enhance its physical security measures to protect its assets and personnel Definitions Governance Document version history
Physical Security Policy.docx

Purpose This procedure describes the activities required to ensure that Wannon Water complies with Records Management and Recordkeeping Legislation, Regulations, Standards and Specifications which all Victorian Government agencies must meet. Strategic and Project Investment Planning processes (incorporate consideration of strategic and operational risk) Hazard and Incident registers (within RiskWare) Wannon Water Audit Program (provides assurance that risk controls are effective) Wannon Water Emergency Management Framework (provides guidance on activities to mitigate, respond to and recover from emergency risks) Zero Harm Management System standards and supporting documents (provide further guidance on requirements to manage risk and meet applicable obligations) Risk Appetite and Permission Statements

Have a medium risk approach to opportunities to strengthen our region Be open to opportunities that have significant potential for increased organisational performance. Risk Management resource Risk management software Budgets to facilitate risk assessment and management processes Risk management training Corporate membership of the Risk Management Institute of Australasia (RMIA) Risk Management Process Figure 3 – Process (ISO 31000:2018) The risk assessment and measurement processes allow Wannon Water to consider the extent to which potential events may have an impact on the achievement of its objectives. This section provides overview of the key steps in the Risk Management process.
